Prompt: Jonathan Herrera [ph] wants to know:

443.text:
What is the one leadership lesson you learned
as a general grade officer that you would

449.text: wished you had known your whole career?

451.text:
You know, you learn all the way through, Jonathan.
At each rank you're learning more, and if

458.text:
there was one lesson that came more and more
into focus over the years, it was one I learned

465.text:
by watching similar-sized units. Like for
example, I watched dozens of platoons go through

471.text:
certain ranges; or I saw companies, dozens
of companies, in fights. I always wondered

477.text:
what made one unit better than another. They
were all well-trained. They all came through

483.text:
the boot camp. All of them --All of them had
been recruited from America and they were

490.text:
quality young men.
So what made them different?

495.text:
It was the junior leadership, the junior NCOs,
the junior officers whose coaching, whose

501.text:
animating spirits brought out the best in
their troops; who had admired leadership.

508.text:
We all know that earning the trust and respect
of your subordinates is critical. You -- You

514.text:
simply have to earn that trust. You have to
earn that respect. You have to earn that every

520.text:
day, because when it's all over and done with
you're not going to win any fights as a leader.

527.text: Your troops are going to win those fights.

530.text:
But there was another word I learned to prioritize
as I evaluated units, and that word was affection.

537.text:
It's not popularity, with all the favoritism
that comes with trying to be a popular person

543.text:
as a leader. That's a -- a road to failure.
But affection that you create in a unit, an

549.text:
affection so strong that the troops will stick
by one another; they'll carry out the mission

555.text:
even in peril. And I bring this one up because
I believe that that kind of affection brings

564.text:
out self-discipline, where people don't want
to let down the unit.

569.text:
And I think that if there is one lesson I
learned along the way -- that the more you

575.text:
can build that kind of affection in a unit,
when the going gets tough, when people are

580.text:

it'll pull through. And it'll be a lot smoother

587.text:

the enemy, more fluidly against the enemy;

592.text:

598.text:
